did.abstract: Ralph J. Bunche (1904-1971) graduated from UCLA and Harvard University, and was a professor at Howard University (1929-1950). He joined the Permanent Secretariat of the United Nations in 1948, served as the undersecretary for special political affairs (1958-67), and then became undersecretary general in 1968. In 1950, Bunche was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize. The collection consists of correspondence, speeches, manuscripts, articles, publications, and photographs related to Ralph J. Bunche's life and career.
did.physloc: Portions of the collection stored off-site. Advance notice is required for access to the collection. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

accessrestrict.p: Open for research. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Family requested that series 21, subseries 1: Personal Correspondence between Ralph J. Bunche and Ruth H. Bunche (boxes 476-480) were closed until the deaths of both Joan H. Bunche and Ralph Bunche Jr. As of April 2021, the family would like to review the materials in these boxes before lifting the restriction.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use and Reproduction
userestrict.p: Series 21, subseries 1: Personal Correspondence between Ralph J. Bunche and Ruth H. Bunche (boxes 476-480) is closed.

processinfo.head: Processing Note
processinfo.p: In 2008-2009 the Bunche Papers were re-processed by Amelia Acker, with assistance from Megan Hahn Fraser, in order to facilitate access with a more consistent arrangement scheme and improved description. Materials were re-organized, and re-housed for better preservation.
A copy of the previous finding aid is maintained on site for researcher reference.
Finding aid updated by Kelly Besser, 2021.

Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Potentially Offensive Description in Library Special Collections.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Bunche, Ralph Johnson (7 Aug. 1904-9 Dec. 1971), scholar and diplomat, was born in Detroit, Michigan, the son of Fred Bunch, a barber, and Olive Agnes Johnson. His grandmother added an "e" to the family's last name following a move to Los Angeles, California. Because his family moved frequently, Bunche attended a number of public schools before graduating first in his class from Jefferson High School in Los Angeles in 1922. He majored in political science at the University of California, Southern Branch (now University of California, Los Angeles or UCLA). He graduated summa cum laude and served as class valedictorian in 1927. He continued his studies in political science at Harvard, receiving his M.A. in 1928, then taught at Howard University in Washington, D.C., while working toward his Ph.D. at Harvard. In 1930 he married Ruth Ethel Harris; they had three children. Bunche traveled to Europe and Africa researching his dissertation and received his Ph.D. from Harvard in February 1934.

Concerned with the problems facing African Americans in the United States, Bunche published numerous articles on racial issues and the monograph A World View of Race (1936). He and his colleague John P. Davis organized a 1935 conference called "The Status of the Negro under the New Deal," at which Bunche criticized the Franklin D. Roosevelt administration and the New Deal. He was also involved in the creation of the National Negro Congress, an attempt to bring white Americans and African Americans of different social and economic backgrounds together to discuss race matters. In the final years of the decade Bunche contributed research and reports to a Carnegie study on American race relations headed by sociologist Gunnar Myrdal. The resulting work, An American Dilemma: The Negro Problem and Modern Democracy, published in 1944, was a landmark study of racial conflicts in the United States.

The rise of totalitarianism in Europe and the outbreak of war in 1939 worried Bunche, who feared that a Nazi victory in Europe would spur the growth of fascism in the United States, with disastrous consequences for African Americans. In 1941 he entered public service, accepting a position as a senior analyst in the Office of the Coordinator of Information (later the Office of Strategic Services). As head of the Africa Section, Bunche urged his superiors to approach the problem of postwar decolonization of European holdings in Africa. His proposal was rejected, and he transferred to the Department of State in 1944.

Bunche served as an adviser to the American delegations at the conferences in Dumbarton Oaks and San Francisco concerning the creation of the United Nations (UN). Recognized for his contributions on colonial and trusteeship policies, he was appointed a member of the U.S. delegation to the 1945 meeting of the Preparatory Commission of the UN and the first session of the UN General Assembly in 1946. In April 1946 Bunche took a temporary position on the United Nations Secretariat as director of the trusteeship position. The temporary position became permanent, and he served on the UN Secretariat for the remainder of his life.

In 1947 Bunche was appointed to the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine. He drafted both the majority report, which recommended a partition of the territory between Palestinians and Jews, and the minority report, which called for the creation of a federal state. The UN General Assembly accepted the partition plan, and Bunche was named the principal secretary for a commission designed to oversee its implementation. With the outbreak of war in 1948, Bunche was appointed as an assistant to the UN mediator, Count Folke Bernadotte. Following Bernadotte's assassination in September of that year, Bunche became the acting mediator. He successfully negotiated armistice agreements between Israel and several Arab states and was awarded the 1950 Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts.

Bunche's commitment to the United Nations did not prevent him from speaking out against racial discrimination in the United States. In 1949 he turned down a position as assistant secretary of state, noting that he did not want to experience the blatant discrimination against African Americans that existed in the nation's capital.

Bunche was appointed an undersecretary-general for special political affairs in 1954. With the outbreak of the Suez crisis in 1956, he was again called upon to use his diplomatic skills in a Middle Eastern conflict, and he organized the UN Emergency Force that was responsible for peacekeeping activities in the region. His Middle East experience prepared him for the difficulties he faced in 1960, when he organized and commanded both the military and civilian branches of the UN peacekeeping force sent to the Congo. He again directed a peacekeeping force when conflicts erupted on the island of Cyprus in 1964.

Bunche continued to press for the civil rights of African Americans. Though he still hoped for a society free from racial division, the civil rights conflicts of the late 1960s troubled him greatly. He participated in the 1965 march from Selma to Montgomery with Martin Luther King, Jr. However, Bunche found himself under attack from leaders, such as Stokely Carmichael and Malcolm X, who argued that he had served white society and abandoned his African heritage. In turn, Bunche denounced the separatist agenda of the Black Power movement. Health problems, many related to his diabetes, slowed him in the final years of his life. He died in New York City.

During his lifetime Bunche garnered international recognition and numerous rewards for his United Nations service, including the U.S. Medal of Freedom in 1963. Though his position earned him the derision of many civil rights leaders in the 1960s, he was dedicated to the cause of African-American civil rights throughout his career. By using his diplomatic skills in the service of the United Nations, he promoted the cause of peace in a world that sorely needed men of dedication and ability in this area.
Thomas Clarkin. "Bunche, Ralph Johnson"; http://www.anb.org/articles/07/07-00424.html ; American National Biography Online Feb. 2000.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Collection consists of correspondence, speeches, manuscripts, articles, publications, photographs, and awards related to the life and career of Ralph J. Bunche. Includes materials related to his teaching and research, his affiliations with various service organizations, educational institutions and international conferences.

The collection includes Bunche's graduate research materials on Africa (photographs and field notes); research and reports from his participation in the Carnegie-Myrdal study on race in the America; U.S. Office of Strategic Services (OSS) reports; Institute of Pacific Relations (IPR) documents; materials related to Bunche's involvement with the United Nations (UN), including Trusteeship records, and materials dealing with his appointment as undersecretary of the UN in 1954; and material related to Bunche's receipt of the Nobel Peace Prize in 1950.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is comprised of exam blue books, class notes, term papers, reports, course notebooks, note cards, and syllabi related to Bunche's course work in law and political science at UCLA. The series also includes the commencement address given by Bunche entitled "The Fourth Dimension of Personality" and his basketball uniform. For letters to Dean C. H. Rieber see Correspondence, series 11.
Course materials are grouped together according to class (e. g. Commercial Law) where appropriate, and arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains materials related to Bunche's studies of government and political science at Harvard Graduate School. Materials include class notebooks, note cards, course materials and syllabi, master's thesis, dissertation field work from Dahomey and Togoland, bibliography note cards and doctoral dissertation on French colonial administration. Outlines from courses taken at Northwestern University in preparation for dissertation fieldwork are also included. The dissertation is complete, although there is no chapter number 2. (Chapters 1 and 2 were renamed Introduction and Chapter 1 upon submission.)
Materials are grouped together by course (e.g. Government 23), then arranged in chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is composed of materials related to Bunche's professional teaching and administrative activities during his chairmanship of the political science department at Howard University from 1928 to 1950. Materials include transmittal correspondence arranged by year and faculty memoranda, student recommendations, course materials, lecture notes, and class record books.
Administrative materials are arranged by type, followed by course materials arranged by course number.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In 1936 Bunche received a two year fellowship from the Social Science Research Council for postdoctoral fieldwork and research in Europe and Africa on colonial administration. This series contains research and reference documents by country/area in Africa, clippings, fieldwork notebooks, note cards, photographs, brief correspondence related to the fellowship, a field diary, and letters of introduction.
Bunche recorded four short films during his fieldwork in Africa and Southeast Asia, which are housed with the Film and Audio Recordings, 1937-1975 series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In 1938 Bunche took leave from Howard University and joined Gunnar Myrdal's survey, "The Negro in America,ÔøΩ commissioned by the Carnegie Corporation. This series includes fieldwork-related correspondence, interviews, field notebooks, research memoranda, questionnaires, maps, note cards, clippings, contact information and reference materials related to Bunche's tours of the southern United States. Additionally, field notes, interviews and memoranda authored by Bunche's survey collaborators Wilhelmina Jackson (later Rolark) and James E. Jackson, Jr. are included. Unless otherwise noted in the folder title, manuscript materials were authored by Bunche.
Materials are maintained in original order by chronology, type of document, and author.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: During World War II, Bunche worked as an African affairs specialist in the Office of the Coordinator of Information (COI) and its successor, the Office of Strategic Services (OSS).This series consists of materials generated by Bunche and his associates at the OSS. Materials include records of interviews, political intelligence reports, geographic studies and surveys, research memoranda, and handwritten notes.

Materials are arranged into nine sub-series: Interviews, Studies and Reports on Africa; French Africa materials; North Africa materials; South Africa materials; Portuguese Africa materials; British Africa materials; Liberia materials; Memoranda and notes; and Surveys on Africa.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of materials generated at the Mont Treblanc, Atlantic City and Hot Springs conferences of the Institute of Pacific Relations (IPR). Materials include published conference agendas, reports, summaries, and brief correspondence related to a Julius Rosenwald Foundation-IPR fellowship to study colonial systems of the Pacific that Bunche was offered but did not accept.
Materials are arranged in chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: During World War II, Bunche worked intermittently at the Department of State but was often ÔøΩon loan' to the Office of Strategic Services. In 1946 Bunche acted as the Chief of the Division of Dependent Area Affairs at the Department of State and was appointed the commissioner of the Anglo-American Caribbean Commission. This series is comprised of administrative materials generated and accumulated by Bunche at the Department of State. Materials include pamphlets, proposals, memoranda, instructional materials, and a telephone directory.
Materials are arranged in chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of materials generated during Bunche's career at the United Nations. Bunche was appointed head of the Trusteeship Division in 1946, which would later become the Trusteeship Council. He served as the assistant to the Special Committee on Palestine and became the principal secretary of the Palestine Committee in 1947. The series is divided into two sub-series: 1) UN General Materials and 2) Trusteeship Council.
Sub-Series Notes:

list.item: This sub-series is made up of working papers that were generated and used by Bunche and his colleagues at the Trusteeship Council. It contains United Nations documentation of Trusteeship Council sessions, including special sessions with other councils; communication with other United Nations Divisions and the International Court of Justice; materials related to Bunche's visiting missions; studies and reports on non-self-governing territories; and official records generated by the General Assembly pertaining to or of special interest to the Trusteeship Council. Boxes 91-93 contain staff files and personnel records of persons employed and promoted by the Trusteeship Council during Bunche's tenure. Some of the official documents contain marginalia by Bunche. Council Sessions are sorted by number of session (e.g. First Session, Second Session); supporting materials are in chronological order by date received; and personnel records are sorted alphabetically by last name of employee.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In 1953, under Executive Order 10422, Bunche was charged with fourteen allegations of disloyalty by the Senate Internal Security Subcommittee. More commonly known as the Loyalty Board Hearings, Bunche answered the fourteen interrogatory charges with an annotated reply (over 100 pages), which included thirty-seven exhibits of original correspondence and supporting documentation. The series contains Bunche's replies to the allegations, original exhibits compiled by Bunche, documents detailing stages of the investigation, rebuttal data, letters of clearance, and newspaper clippings about the event.
Materials were maintained in original order, with exhibits in order by allegation number.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Correspondence series contains letters, cablegrams, and invitations between Bunche and his academic and professional colleagues; professional, academic and service organizations; educational institutions; religious organizations; sororities and fraternities; family friends and the public. Bunche's correspondence with colleagues, organizations and the public detail his responsibilities to the United Nations, and highlight his commitment to peacekeeping, democracy and civil rights throughout the world. This series includes correspondence with many notable persons such as Trygve Lie, Dag Hammarskjold, U Thant, Adlai Stevenson, Count Folke Bernadotte, Eleanor Roosevelt, Alain Locke, Melville Herskovits, Martin Luther King, Jackie Robinson, Malcolm X, Walter White, W.E.B. Du Bois, Cecil Roberts, William Hastie, Charles Matthews, and a few items from each President of the United States from Franklin Roosevelt to Richard Nixon.

The series is organized chronologically by year, then alphabetically by correspondent. Some subject specific correspondence was maintained together and appears at the end of the alphabetical arrangement (e.g., "Correspondence Z, 1960ÔøΩ is followed by "Correspondence, Congo mission, A-F, 1960ÔøΩ). Hate mail (usually with Bunche's annotation "arsenic ÔøΩ) and social invitations appear at the end of each year. Social invitations are also found in Boxes 266-276.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Found in this series are Bunche's desk calendars, personal and appointment diaries, and notes and notebooks. The desk calendars are the page-a-day format, listing appointments and sometimes notes on activities and conversations. Only pages with notes were retained. The annual diaries from 1937 and 1938 contain longer entries about travels, activities and events in Bunche's life. The pocket diaries are more like calendars in nature, and contain brief notes on appointments. The notes and notebooks range in content from brief descriptions of a conversation or event, to longer journals describing trips, conferences and meetings.
Items are arranged chronologically by format.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bunche was a member of many educational, philanthropic and political organizations. He sat on the board of trustees, board of directors and a variety of planning committees for numerous institutions and universities over the course of his lifetime. This series is comprised of printed materials generated by organizational activities that were sent to and collected by Bunche as a part of his membership duties. Materials include agendas, correspondence related to meetings, invitations, newsletters, bulletins, meeting minutes, meeting notices, memoranda, and conference materials.

Materials are arranged in alphabetical order by name of organization or institution. Folder titles list the organization, Bunche's capacity of membership if known, and a brief description of the documents therein (e.g. "Lincoln University, Board of Trustees. Meeting notices, memoranda, and reportsÔøΩ).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of Bunche's original speeches, academic lectures, commencement addresses and remarks given at events and recorded interviews and statements that were broadcast on radio or television programs. In many cases manuscript drafts, reading copies, and transcripts with annotations and marginalia exist for speeches and broadcasts. Folders often include correspondence and supporting documents related to the event where the speech took place, including programs and reprints. Acceptance speeches for honorary degrees and awards are also included in this series. Some recordings of interviews and television broadcasts, including Bunche's Person to Person interview with Edward R. Murrow, are housed with the Film and Audio Recordings 1937-1975 series.
Materials are arranged in chronological order, with speaking engagement schedules and general materials related to broadcasted recordings at the beginning of each year.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is comprised of articles, manuscripts, publications and statements written by Bunche over the course of his academic and diplomatic career. Topics discussed in Bunche's works include democracy, the role of the United Nations in the world, peace and peacekeeping, race, and human rights. Folders may include original manuscript drafts, edited drafts, reprints, off-prints and correspondence related to publication.
Materials are arranged chronologically then alphabetically by title of work.

scopecontent.p: The article addresses the issue of increasing participation of African Americans in Chicago politics. scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains photographs of Bunche throughout his entire life, beginning with his early childhood and ending with his final days at the United Nations. Bunche is pictured in candid shots and portraits with many notable figures of the day, and colleagues from Harvard University, Howard University and the United Nations. Also included are photographs of Bunche at social events, often accompanied by his wife or other family member, and at speaking engagements or other ceremonies. Persons pictured include Trygve Lie, Dag Hammarskjold, U Thant, Adlai Stevenson, Count Folke Bernadotte, Moshe Dayan, General William Riley, Jawaharlal Nehru, Eleanor Roosevelt, Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit, Moise Tshombe, Patrice Lumumba, John F. Kennedy, Lyndon B. Johnson, Jacqueline Kennedy, Brian Urquhart, Jackie Robinson, Marc Chagall, Martin Luther King and Coretta Scott King, and many others. Many photographs were taken by United Nations photographers, as indicated on the verso.

Photographs are arranged chronologically. Three or more photographs of a particular event or trip are filed separately within each year (e.g., "Photographs 1960ÔøΩ is followed by "Photographs, Somalia, January 1960. Family photographs are found at the beginning of this series.

did.unittitle: Ralph J. Bunche confers with President Makarios

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On verso of photograph: UN 84460, Nicosia, Cyprus, 8 April 1964. Ralph J. Bunche, Under-Secretary for Special Political Affairs, met with President Makarios on 8 April 1964, during his visit to Cyprus. Mr. Bunche visited Cyprus in the course of a routine visit to study the problems and needs of the United Nations truce supervision and peace force operations in Gaza, Cyprus and Kashmir on instructions from the Secretary-General. The missions include the United Nations Emergency Force (UNEF), the United Nations Force in Cyprus (UNFICYP) and the United Nations Military Observer Group in India and Pakistan (UNMOGIP). Includes the following description of photograph: Dr. Ralph J. Bunche (left) Under-Secretary for Special Political Affairs, conferring with Archbishop Makarios, President of the Republic of Cyprus, in the Presidential Palace in Nicosia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains honorary degrees, awards, certificates of recognition, trophies and plaques awarded to Bunche. Also found in this series are materials related to his receipt of the Nobel Peace Prize (1950). City and state resolutions in honor of Bunche also appear in this series.

Materials are arranged into the following four sub-series: Honorary Degrees; Awards, Citations and Honors; Nobel Prize Materials; and Medals, Plaques, and Trophies. Materials are arranged within each sub- series by chronology or appropriate housing size.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains newspaper clippings and scrapbooks about Bunche and his work at the United Nations; it also includes publications that feature Bunche in some way or were inscribed to him. In most cases the scrapbooks were compiled and created by Ruth H. Bunche, and feature clippings and magazine covers from Bunche's early life, his United Nations career and peace work, and his family life.

This series is organized into three sub-series by type: Clippings; Scrapbooks; and Publications received. Clippings and Publications are arranged by date. Many scrapbooks contain dated materials that overlap with other books, and are thus arranged by size and housing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains film and audio recordings that feature Bunche, including interviews and speeches; career highlights; dedication ceremonies; and recordings made by Bunche during his SSRC postdoctoral fieldwork in Africa. It also contains video recordings of a press conference featuring the Bunche papers exhibit at UCLA in 1975, a UCLA Founder's Day tribute to Bunche, and a recording of Shirley Ellis.
Materials are arranged by format and then by date. Reader copies for most of the original recordings exist; please see staff regarding special arrangements for use of these materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains papers of a personal nature and papers pertaining to Bunche's relatives, and is divided into five subseries.
Sub-series notes:
21.1 Personal correspondence: This subseries contains letters between Ralph and Ruth Bunche. This material is closed until after the deaths of Joan H. Bunche and Ralph Bunche, Jr.

21.2 Ralph Bunche: This subseries includes records relating to Bunche's employment, personal finances, and property. Letters of appointment and resignation, per diem applications and leave forms, pension and benefits information for Bunche's jobs with the Office of Strategic Services, the United Nations and Harvard University, resumes and questionnaires for biographical dictionaries, income tax forms, receipts, wills, insurance policies and other items will be found in this subseries. Also included is correspondence and documents pertaining to the unauthorized biography, "Ralph Bunche: Fighter for PeaceÔøΩ written by J. Alvin Kugelmass, and correspondence, scripts and other documents pertaining to the film "Toward Tomorrow: the Ralph Bunche-Lucy Johnson Story.ÔøΩ

21.3 Ruth Bunche: This subseries contains education and employment records, passports, wills and estate appraisals for Ruth Bunche. Also included are drafts of an essay and a letter to the editor of the New York Times that were handwritten by Ralph Bunche, but published under Ruth Bunche's name.

21.4 Family Papers: This subseries includes family history compositions by Bunche's aunts Nelle and Ethel Johnson, reminiscences about Bunche's grandmother Lucy Johnson, and correspondence and souvenirs related to Bunche's children Joan, Jane and Ralph, Jr.

21.5 Memorials and tributes: This subseries consists of materials about the disposition of Bunche's papers and effects, the monument "Peace Form One,ÔøΩ dedicated to his memory in Ralph Bunche Park at the United Nations, the commemorative postage stamp of his likeness issued in 1982, and the use of his name in publication and for schools and scholarships.
